item.title: Ticket #6410 (DB_COLLATE is not used in database queries) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description:
when SAVEQUERIES is turned on, the first query always is: 

[0]=>
  array(3) {
    [0]=>
    string(16) "SET NAMES 'utf8'"
    [1]=>
    float(0.00020217895507812)
    [2]=>
    string(12) "require_once"

doesn't this mean db_collate is actually used?

D.

item.title: Ticket #6754 (Improve default wp_salt()) updated
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description: Okay, how about the second patch? I guess there really isn't a great advantage to including the database password anyways: if you can get the file modified time, you can probably read wp-config.php anyways.

item.title: better_wp_salt_prefix2.diff attached to Ticket #6754
item.dc:creator: filosofo

item.title: Ticket #6754 (Improve default wp_salt()) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: I'd rather not introduce DB_PASSWORD into cookie key creation in any way. Best to avoid any possibility of DB_PASSWORD being brute forced. Can we make do with just mtime and only use it in the recipe only if SECRET_KEY is not defined? An admin might not want to expire cookies for everyone whenever wp-config.php is changed. I certainly wouldn't want that on wordpress.com.

item.title: Ticket #6754 (Improve default wp_salt()) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: Clever solution. At first glance this seems like a good bet.

item.title: better_wp_salt_prefix.diff attached to Ticket #6754
item.dc:creator: filosofo

item.title: Ticket #6754 (Improve default wp_salt()) created
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
As pointed out â€‹here, if someone gets the salt from db and SECRET_KEY is default or blank, the password security is no better off than it was in 2.3.3.

My patch adds a md5 hash of the time wp-config.php was last modified and the database password, as a prefix to the secret key. Neither should be available just from obtaining a database dump, and particularly the time wp-config.php was last modified should be difficult to determine, so that should reduce the effectiveness of such an attack as described above.

item.title: Ticket #6753 (Autosave changes draft post's author) created
item.dc:creator: MtDewVirus
item.description:
Autosave is changing the draft post's author when another user makes changes.

Steps to reproduce:

  1. Create and save a draft post with user1
  2. Logout
  3. Login with user2
  4. Edit the draft
  5. Wait for autosave
  6. Go back to Manage->Posts and see the author has changed

Tested using r7693.

item.title: Ticket #6751 (wp_mime_type_icon() no longer supports custom media icons) created
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Support for custom media icons, as described â€‹here, has been gutted from wp_mime_type_icon(). The crystal icons are hard coded.

ADDITIONAL DETAILS (to add finding this ticket)

from â€‹http://codex.wordpress.org/Theme_Development#Media_Icons

Wordpress uses media icons to represent attachment files on your blog and in the Admin interface, if those icons are available.

It looks for image files named by media type in the images directory of the current theme.

For example, for an attachment of MIME type audio/mpeg, Wordpress would look for an icon file at these locations, stopping after the first match (see wp_mime_type_icon):

item.title: Ticket #6750 (Changing User Roles Removes Role) created

If you create a new user, the user is created without a role.

Tested on 2 different installs of r7693 with a user account set as Administrator.

item.title: Ticket #6746 (can't we cache _get_post_ancestors()?) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description:
further investigation leads me to identify get_permalink() as the likely culprit for the insane number of queries.

brings me to a thought: isn't reasonable to assume that, if at one point another a page gets queried, there's a 99% change that get_permalink() will get called? if so, it would make sense to get all the ancestors and their details whenever they're not in the cache already.

D.

item.title: Ticket #6737 (TinyMCE converts relative links incorrectly (adds wp-admin)) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Another possibility: Hook it to a setting. The "WordPress should correct invalidly nested XHTML automatically" seems to apply here. If they have that turned off, then it would not adjust the urls at all. If they have it turned on, it would make them absolute.

Regardless of that, the document base needs to be set to make it work correctly. As it stands now, that's causing the wp-admin insertion resulting in invalid links most of the time.

item.title: Ticket #6748 (wp_list_pages can cause huge numbers of SQL queries) created
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Report here: â€‹http://wordpress.org/support/topic/167000?replies=18#post-732526

Summary: wp_list_pages makes use of the Walker_Page class. Walker_Page calls get_page() which calls get_post() which calls _get_post_ancestors() which is not cached.

On a large set of pages, the _get_post_ancestors() function being called this often can result in a huge amount of queries to the database, all taking this form: SELECT post_parent FROM wp_posts WHERE ID= 'page_id' LIMIT 1

When you have nested pages in a large hierarchy, this rapidly grows obscene in terms of the number of queries performed, since it must execute one query to track each page back to the root of the hierarchy.

Example: /pageroot/ /pageroot/1/ /pageroot/1/2/ /pageroot/1/3/ /pageroot/1/4/

Doing a wp_list_pages on the above set of pages results in 12 separate queries to the database, just to get post_parents. Adding just one more subpage, like /pageroot/1/2/5/ will add 4 more queries.

Problems reported in the support forum have gotten up to 2000+ queries from one call to wp_list_pages.

item.title: Ticket #6747 (function maybe_create_table() declared in two files) created
item.dc:creator: mastermind
item.description:
The function maybe_create_table() is a nice helper for plugins that need to create a database table. As it is not available by default, one has to include the file which contains this function. So far so good.

However, maybe_create_table() is declared in /wp-admin/install-helper.php as well as in /wp-admin/includes/upgrade.php.

If, as a matter of coincidence, both of the above files are loaded, then this will of course throw a "Fatal error: Cannot redeclare maybe_create_table() in /var/www/htdocs/elnl.zirona.de/wp-admin/includes/upgrade.php on line 735"

This is not only theoretical, but I actually encountered this in the following situation:

A plugin of mine uses a function activate_plugin(), called via register_activation_hook(__FILE__, 'activate_plugin');. That function loads /wp-admin/install-helper.php to use the function maybe_create_table(). When I tried to import content to the blog (Manage -> Import -> WordPress), the page would die with the Fatal error.

The solution was to temporarily deactivate the table creating routine from the activation function.

item.title: Ticket #6746 (can't we cache _get_post_ancestors()?) updated
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description:
figures for a site with 90 static pages:

@ init hook: 7 queries - 0.160 seconds @ template_redirect hook: 11 queries - 0.183 seconds @ wp_footer hook: 153 queries - 0.403 seconds

the 153 queries (almost all related to _get_post_ancestors()) take as much as a second every now and then...

item.title: Ticket #6746 (can't we cache _get_post_ancestors()?) created
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description: It seems there's a reason for not doing so, but when your site has a hundred static pages, displaying the pages widget readily takes a second or more...

item.title: Ticket #6744 (Include upgrade warnings in a read me or other notification system) updated
item.dc:creator: MichaelH
item.description:
Type changed

The development blog does try to inform users of most changes. But, it is quite a job to describe ALL the changes to functionality in a release, especially for major releases such as 2.5. Some features, changes, and bug fixes, just get lost in the glitz of all the other 'stuff'.

During the development cycle it is helpful to read â€‹Peter Westwood and his weekly digest of changes made to WordPress trunk.

Belonging to the â€‹Trac email list is useful for keeping up with all the Trac activity. Subscribers to that email list saw several emails in February about the behavior change to 'the more' in feeds (Ticket: #2582).

For the interested users, belonging to the â€‹Testers email list, and the â€‹Hackers email list, can provide a continuing glimpse of what's happening on 'the development scene.'

In the past, in Codex, a huge effort went into documenting the new features with each release. Lloyd Budd, in particular, spent quite a bit of time fleshing out the details for â€‹Version 2.3. There is a â€‹Version 2.6 article that will need some love. Hopefully, someone will take ownership of that article and expand it as features are added or changed.

Conclusion: -1 for adding a readme file to the distribution. The development blog just feels like the best place for this kind of information. Users that would, or could, access a readme file, are likely the same users that follow the community email lists.

item.title: Ticket #6745 (2.5: white screen when inserting image in post) created
item.dc:creator: windansea
item.description:
Hi,

I followed and tried all the suggestions 1-9 in the sticky 'image media uploader problem' forumtopic by 'Otto42'.

Only the final step is missing: I cannot insert the image in the post. The screen turns white and nothing happens (IE6 and Firefox/2.0.0.13. Seeing more posts about this problem, I'm no exception this time.

But what is missing is a fix, explanation or way to search to find the solution.

Thanks!

item.title: Ticket #6600 (error in function gallery_shortcode (wp-includes/media.php)) updated
item.dc:creator: noledge
item.description:
Replying to mhubi:

i have the exact same problem on the same platform (debian 4.0, php 5.2) i had PHP4 first when i upgraded to WP2.5, which worked fine. after upgrading to PHP5, no gallerys were shown in posts, and the same mysql error was drawn into the logs. the above workaround fixed this for me, though i have no idea why this worked in PHP4.

item.title: Ticket #6744 (Include upgrade warnings in a read me or other notification system) created
item.dc:creator: hexley
item.description:
The main point of my issue at â€‹http://trac.wordpress.org/ticket/6680 went largely ignored.

Wordpress needs some method of alerting users before upgrading of what changes have been made that may effect their install. I was fully unaware that a change had been made to how the <!--more--> tag works in regards to RSS feeds. I rely on RSS feeds for my advertisers. Updating to 2.5 truncated my posts at a hard coded limit, or I had to show full feeds.

While this can be fixed with a plug-in now, I would have solved that pre-upgrade, had I only known.

A changelog is too verbose for the casual user. Expecting users to search trac is asking too much of casual users.

If functionality is removed, or changed, from a past version, that users rely on, there should be clear warnings in a file in the download archive.

item.title: Ticket #6743 (preview button in admin no longer performs a save before previewing) created
item.dc:creator: hexley
item.description:
Pre 2.5, clicking the preview button in the admin interface would also save the post. If you preview a post before the scheduled auto-save kicks in, you will not see your changes in the preview page.

Prior to version 2.5, clicking preview would first save the page, then show you an up to date preview.

item.title: 6742.patch attached to Ticket #6742
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond

item.title: Ticket #6742 (Add hook for translating English) created
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
I want to be able to make __('foo') return bar, even if the blog is in English. If WordPress is in any other language besides English, I think you can just use the "gettext" filter to do this. However, my blog is in English, so you can't.

Attached patch adds a backwards compatible pre-translating hook for allowing plugins to switch phrases before they are translated.

It also passes the domain to "gettext" filter for the hell of it.

item.title: Ticket #6709 (Usability changes to write post and write page panels) updated
item.dc:creator: jabecker
item.description:
P.S. re: â€‹#6635, it does not include the change to display the list of drafts at the top.

The reason that I find that function so helpful is because otherwise from the write page, I can't even tell I have drafts saved. With the way that auto-save works now, I ended up with several drafts that I had never intended creating. I realized they were there because I say it on the dashboard. But I don't go to the dashboard very often. I found it really annoying to have to go over to a separate list to find and delete the extraneous drafts. The list is really helpful information.

item.title: Ticket #6709 (Usability changes to write post and write page panels) updated
item.dc:creator: jabecker
item.description:
I'm using my own changes and have found the layout much preferable to the new WP 2.5 layout.

The Category drop-down lists either all categories or most used categories already. I don't have a ton of categories, true, but there is room at the side to list them. And I can always close the menu when I'm done selecting the categories I want.

I am also using the plugin Simple Tags. It includes tag lists and tag suggestions. The tag lists appear in a scrollable box below the tag input. Again, there's plenty of room for the box to extend down quite a ways before it needs to start scrolling, and I can close the menu when I'm finished with tags.

Don't get me wrong - I'd love to have automatic tag suggestions. But I don't see why that requires a wider area than what's available in the sidebar.

item.title: Ticket #6741 (in_category not working in WP 2.5 - ignores category id/name) created
item.dc:creator: TrishaM
item.description:
Used the following code as suggested in the Codex for in_category, however, in all cases regardless of the actual category ID that the post has assigned to it, the second include-file is being served.

`<?php

$post = $wp_query->post;

if (in_category(16)) {

include(TEMPLATEPATH . '/single-cat-16.php'); }

else {

include(TEMPLATEPATH . '/singleproduct.php'); }

?>`

item.title: Ticket #6737 (TinyMCE converts relative links incorrectly (adds wp-admin)) updated
item.dc:creator: azaozz
item.description:
Another option is to add 

'convert_urls' => false,

which would keep the URLs as entered. That was the setting in TinyMCE 2.x, but had to be changed as it wasn't working well with the "media" plugin. However since the last update to TinyMCE 3.0.7, it's working as expected.

So the question is: shall we force absolute URLs that will prevent them from breaking when custom permalinks are used (although a few users would complain about TinyMCE/WordPress changing their links), or shall we let the users enter any type of URL despite that it may break if permalinks are changed.

item.title: Ticket #6739 (smilie regular expression issue) created
item.dc:creator: hailin
item.description:
There is an issue with $wp_smiliessearch, it will miss some valid smilies. For example, for :) the pattern is: /(\s|)\:\)(\s|$)/

If the input is ":) :) :) :)" It will produce only two smilies.

The fix is to change the pattern to: /(\s*|)\:\)(\s|$)/

item.title: Ticket #6737 (TinyMCE converts relative links incorrectly (adds wp-admin)) created
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
TinyMCE has a feature that auto-converts relative links to absolute ones. This is a good thing for WordPress, since anybody using non-default permalinks needs this feature for their links to work.

The problem is that TinyMCE in 2.5 is converting all the relative links as if they are in the wp-admin path. This is breaking image insertion as well, for some people.

The root cause is the lack of a defined "document_base_url" setting. When TinyMCE cannot find one, it uses the current url of the page it's in, which happens to be the write page in wp-admin.

Possible, but untested, fix is to add this to the tiny-mce-config.php file: 

'document_base_url' => get_option('url'),

This should set the site root as the correct base and allow it to convert the relative links correctly, as the user would expect it to convert them.

item.title: Ticket #6736 (Image Uploader and Suhosin Extension) updated
item.dc:creator: stevish
item.description: Aaaand, I'm an idiot. When I added the php.ini file I didn't realize that I basically set all other options to their defaults. So the answer to the problem is somewhere in the php.ini settings, and the defaults do work, but it has nothing to do with max_execution_time. I'm currently going through option-by-option to see if I can find the culprit. Please stand by.

item.title: 6579.patch attached to Ticket #6579
item.dc:creator: spirit55555

item.title: Ticket #6599 (Inpage URLs can be realtive instead of being always absolute.) closed
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description: invalid

item.title: Ticket #6599 (Inpage URLs can be realtive instead of being always absolute.) reopened
item.dc:creator: Otto42

item.title: Ticket #6599 (Inpage URLs can be realtive instead of being always absolute.) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description: Milestone changed

item.title: Ticket #6599 (Inpage URLs can be realtive instead of being always absolute.) closed
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
wontfix:

This is incorrect. Replacing these absolute URLs with relative ones will break all non-default permalink systems.

Recognize that relative URLs work in one of two ways:

  • from root
  • from the current URL

Using root level relative URLs would break WordPress's ability to be easily installed in a subdirectory of a site.

Using current URL relative links breaks permalinks, because the point of permalinks is that they bear no relationship to the underlying file system structure of the site. What is a single relative link to, say, a CSS file that works when the current URL is both â€‹http://example.com/blog/ and â€‹http://example.com/blog/2008/04/15/single-post/ ?

No, we use absolute URLs for a very good reason, and those absolute URLs are built on the fly from the settings. The site remains portable when coded correctly (using bloginfo('url') calls and similar to display the root URL instead of hardcoding it.

Closing this as invalid.

item.title: Ticket #6513 (Older/Newer Post error in classic Theme) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Replying to stevegk:

Reading the codex entry â€‹http://codex.wordpress.org/Next_and_Previous_Links the patch also goes against the documentation. It seems that the function is returning next results when it should return previous results and vice versa.

No, the codex was just wrong/confusing. I fixed it.

Basically, the problem is that "previous" and "next" are not referring to chronological time, they are referring to pages and post ordering.

Post ordering is arbitrary. It defaults to "post_date DESC", but it can be anything, really. If you change the query_posts to put it in ASC ordering, then the oldest post will show up first, and the previous/next links won't change. Oh, they'll point to different posts, but they'll still point to the previous/next posts in the given ordering.

"Next" refers to the next post in the given ordering, whatever it may be. By default, "next" = "older posts". This is admittedly confusing if you think of next as forward in time, but it is actually forward in the returned set of posts from the database, whatever order they may be in.

item.title: Ticket #6736 (Image Uploader and Suhosin Extension) created
item.dc:creator: stevish
item.description:
This may be something you choose not to change, but I thought I'd shed some light on it:

With the media uploader, if the max_execution_time is set to 30 (Which was the default on my host), on any page that displays more than 37 images (such as gallery where there are 60 pictures), you cannot edit any pictures beyond the 37th one (or right around there). You can "show" them, and change the fields, but when you click on "Save all changes", only the changes on the first 37 images will be saved. Also, the "Insert into post" button does not work right beyond the 37th image.

I really don't think it's an actual time-out issue, because for me (with the max_execution_time set to 30) the script was finishing in 3-5 seconds... not 30. I am assuming that there is some piece of code somewhere that causes the max_execution_time to be improperly used or something... I haven't been able to find anything (though I am not a very learned programmer).

Can anyone else verify this? Set max_execution_time to 30 and max_input_time (don't know if it does anything) to 60, and see if you can edit the first and last pictures in a gallery with 50 pictures (using a tab that shows all 50 at once).

item.title: Ticket #6735 (File upload limit - error message) created
item.dc:creator: simonwheatley
item.description:
To reproduce:

  1. In php.ini, set post_max_size to something very low (e.g. 1K)
  1. Restart Apache
  1. Create a new post, and upload a file of over 1Kb.
  1. The error message makes mention of upload_max_filesize, but not post_max_size.

The attached patch amends the error message to mention both php.ini values (post_max_size & upload_max_filesize).

There are implications for localisation with this patch, in that it changes a localised string.

item.dc:creator: dara_masala
item.description:
The editor also adds an empty line after each line. This empty line disappears after saving and comes back again when editing the post. To reproduce:

  1. Browse to write a new post.
  2. Switch to HTML view.
  3. Write something with several lines between pre tags.
  4. Switch to Visual view - there is an empty line after each line.

This happens in firefox and ie6 (I didn't test with other browsers).

Doron

item.title: Ticket #6733 (gallery html issue) created
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description:
if you insert a floating div at the beginning of the content, and follow it with a gallery, it looks absolutely horrible. e.g. 

<div style="float: left;">an author image</div>
[gallery]

the best fix, I believe, would be to automatically insert the following before the gallery code: 

<div style="clear: both;></div>

item.title:
Ticket #6444 (Changeset 7561 (post rc3) leaves an open

at the end of the ...) updated
item.dc:creator: AaronCampbell
item.description:
I wasn't real interested in it at first either. I doubt I'll ever really need it, because I don't mind marking up the content I send it. However, I was aiming for two things:

1) Backwards compatibility. I wasn't sure how many plugin authors had already been developing using the existing method, assuming that their content would be formatted by WP.

2) There are a lot of less-than-thorough (I put that as nicely as I could) plugin developers, who need their content cleaned up just as badly as regular users do.

I want to make it clear that in the end, I'm completely happy with either way. I had already started with my fix before I found this ticket, so I figured I'd go ahead and offer it as a suggestion. It's definitely more complex/convoluted, but it's also slightly more flexible.

item.title:
Ticket #6444 (Changeset 7561 (post rc3) leaves an open

at the end of the ...) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Hm, I wasn't too interested in letting people have it both ways, but your method gets around the problem of an inline shortcode being used on its own line and not getting paragraph-wrapped.

For example, if I had a [myname] shortcode that outputted "Mark Jaquith" and I did: 

foo paragraph
[myname]
bar paragraph

I'd end up with: 

<p>foo paragraph</p>
Mark Jaquith
<p>bar paragraph</p>

But with your patch I could just set that shortcode to run at 9 and it'd take care of it.

item.title: Ticket #6702 (Raise in the Wordpress number of queries in nested pages) updated
item.dc:creator: tiosolid
item.description: Hi, i tried to change the (!isset) to (isset) but still the queries problem appeared. The unique way to solve my high mysql usage was to comment out the While statment from the get_post_ancestors function. Since this is probably going to break something somewhere, is there any other way to fix this?

item.title: Ticket #6716 (Permalink slug not fully editable) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
Replying to cyndin:

Blog stats is a plugin for 2.3 and earlier but I think it's been integrated into WP 2.5 (I may be wrong). Anyway, it's not a bug of the stats program. All it's doing is grabbing the slug line from somewhere it is stored. The issue is that it's stored wrong in at least one place.

It's not in the core, it's just better integrated into WordPress when used.

And it is a plugin (well, not even the plugin really) issue as all stats are pulled off a remote server. The remote WP.com server is probably holding a copy of your old slug.

item.title: Ticket #6556 (Impossible to move text/rss widgets between sidebars) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
The code was rather crude behind the scenes, plus you had to refresh the page to add more / remove widget instances. The definable number also was a hard cap on the number of widget instances you could have. You can now have 100 text widgets if you want, something you couldn't do in the old versions.

But as I said before, being able to move widgets directly from one sidebar to another would be a very handy feature, one I fully support.

item.title: Ticket #6680 (Full post RSS feeds can not break at the <!--more--> point) updated
item.dc:creator: hexley
item.description:
Well, I do not see it in there, searching for --more-- or RSS. Not that I do not believe you :-) I just did an update to MySql, they made clear, in the download, in a read me, that if you update from version 4.x to 5.x, the way timestamp works has fully changed. I needed to make code changes to deal with it.

I decided to hold off on that update.

I updated to WP 2.5, and no longer had summary feeds, and no longer could inject paid for ads into them, as functionality changed. There absolutely needs to be a read me in the download, warning people about expected behavior changing.

I do not care that this feature changed, fine, I can always work around it. People need to know ahead of time.

item.title: query-php-break-statement.diff attached to Ticket #6731
item.dc:creator: torfason
item.description: Patch to fix the bug, by inserting a break into the statement

item.title: Ticket #6731 (edit-pages.php does not correctly order pages by menu_order) created
item.dc:creator: torfason
item.description:
In version 2.5, as well as in the most recent checkout, the list of pages generated by edit-pages.php does not correctly order pages by the menu_order column. The reason is the lack of a break statement in query.php, which causes the menu_order case to fall through to the next case and the $orderby variable gets set to $wpdb->posts.ID.

A patch detailing an insertion of this break statement is attached, which seems to fix the problem.
